'''Celebration''' is a [[census-designated place]] (CDP) and a [[master-planned community]] in [[Osceola County, Florida]], United States, located near [[Walt Disney World Resort]] and originally developed by [[The Walt Disney Company]]. As part of the [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]]–[[Kissimmee, Florida|Kissimmee]] [[Greater Orlando|Metropolitan Statistical Area]], Celebration's population was 7,427 at the [[2010 United States Census|2010 census]].<ref name="Census 2010">{{cite web|url=http://factfinder2.census.gov |title=Race, Hispanic or Latino, Age, and Housing Occupancy: 2010 Census Redistricting Data (Public Law 94-171) Summary File (QT-PL), Celebration CDP, Florida |website=U.S. Census Bureau, American FactFinder 2 |accessdate=August 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130911234518/http://factfinder2.census.gov/ |archivedate=September 11, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref>
Subsequent to founding Celebration, Disney followed its plans<ref name="nyt01">{{cite news| title = Disney Is Selling a Town It Built to Reflect the Past| newspaper = The New York Times| author = Goodnough, Abby| date = January 16, 2004| url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E06E5D91E30F935A25752C0A9629C8B63&scp=3&sq=celebration%20florida%20disney&st=cse| accessdate = January 16, 2004}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> to divest most of its control of the town. Several Disney business units continue to occupy the town's office buildings, and two utility companies, Smart City Telecom and [[Reedy Creek Energy Services]], both operated from Walt Disney World, provide services to the town. The town itself remains directly connected to the Walt Disney World resorts via one of its primary streets, World Drive, which begins near the [[Magic Kingdom]].
Downtown Celebration's post office was designed by [[Michael Graves]], the adjacent Welcome Center by [[Philip Johnson]], and the Celebration Health building by [[Robert A. M. Stern]].<ref name="nyt2">{{cite news | title = At Celebration, Some Reasons to Celebrate | newspaper = The New York Times|author= Riddle, Lyn|date=March 7, 1999| url = https://www.nytimes.com/1999/03/07/realestate/at-celebration-some-reasons-to-celebrate.html}}</ref> Other nearby buildings are designed by well-known architects including: [[Charles Willard Moore|Charles Moore]] (Preview Center), [[Graham Gund]] (Bohemian Hotel), [[Cesar Pelli]] (movie theatre), [[Robert Venturi]] and [[Denise Scott Brown]] (SunTrust Bank).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.celebration.fl.us/walking-tour-2/|title=Architectural walking tour description|website=Celebration.fl.us|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120730040007/http://www.celebration.fl.us/walking-tour-2/|archivedate=July 30, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==History== In the early 1990s, the [[Disney Development Company]] (DDC) established the Celebration Company to spearhead its development within approximately {{convert|4900|acre|km2}} of land in the southern portion of the [[Reedy Creek Improvement District]].<ref>Davis, Brandy (April 1997). "[http://www.impactpress.com/articles/aprmay97/celebrat.htm New Urbanism: Cause for Celebration?]", Impact Press. Retrieved on October 20, 2007.</ref> Total investment for the project is estimated at US$2.5 billion.<ref>{{cite book|last=Frantz|first=Douglas|author2=Catherine Collins|title=Celebration, U.S.A.: Living in Disney's Brave New Town|date=September 9, 1999|publisher=Henry Holt and Company|isbn=0-8050-5560-6|page=23}}</ref>
The master plan was developed by [[Cooper, Robertson & Partners]] and [[Robert A. M. Stern]], and the extensive landscape, parks, trails and pathways were designed by the San Francisco firm EDAW (now [[AECOM]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edaw.com/ |title=Design, Planning and Environments Worldwide |publisher=EDAW |date=August 18, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090925090624/http://www.edaw.com/ |archivedate=September 25, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Celebration is planned in an early 20th-century architectural style and is not zoned for high-density residences. Celebration was named the "New Community of the Year" in 2001 by the Urban Land Institute.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cincinnati.uli.org/AwardsAndCompetitions/AwardsForExcellenceProgram/2001/Celebration.aspx |title=The Urban Land Institute |publisher=Cincinnati.uli.org |accessdate=October 2, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819051127/http://www.cincinnati.uli.org/AwardsAndCompetitions/AwardsForExcellenceProgram/2001/Celebration.aspx |archivedate=August 19, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The first phase of residential development occurred in the summer of 1996 with Celebration Village, West Village, and Lake Evalyn; this was followed by the North Village, South Village, East Village and Aquila Reserve and the final Artisan Park phases.<ref name="generalinfo">[http://www.celebration.fl.us/celpress/celebrationpress.pdf Celebration, Florida – General Information] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070104095739/http://www.celebration.fl.us/celpress/celebrationpress.pdf |date=January 4, 2007 }} (December 2005)</ref> Disney CEO [[Michael Eisner]] took an especially keen interest in the development of the new town in the early days, encouraging the executives at Disney Development Company to "make history" and develop a town worthy of the Disney brand and legacy that extended to Walt Disney's vision of an [[Experimental Prototype Community of Tomorrow]] (EPCOT). DDC executives collaborated extensively with leaders in education, health, and technology in addition to planners and architects to create the vision and operating policies for the town.
Later phases included construction by a number of developers, including David Waronker.<ref name="PinoBuildIt">{{cite news|last1=Pino|first1=Mark|title=IF CELEBRATION WANTS A SCHOOL, IT WILL BUILD IT|url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/280032287/fulltext/1277CC1B0E55416CPQ/56?accountid=10226|accessdate=20 March 2018|publisher=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|date=5 February 2003}}</ref>
==Geography== Celebration is located at {{Coord|28|19|12|N|81|32|25|W|type:city}} (28.320059, −81.540149).<ref name="GR1">{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/geo/www/gazetteer/gazette.html|publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]]|accessdate=2011-04-23|date=2011-02-12|title=US Gazetteer files: 2010, 2000, and 1990}}</ref>
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the CDP has a total area of {{convert|10.7|sqmi}}, of which {{convert|0.04|sqmi}}, or 0.28%, is water.
Celebration is under USPS [[ZIP code]] 34747, sometimes known as [[Kissimmee, Florida|Kissimmee]]. This is due to the city being [[Municipal corporation|unincorporated]], as Celebration is not a subdivision and is still considered an unincorporated town.
==Demographics== [[File:022306-CelebrationFL09.2.jpg|thumb|left|Bank of America building, downtown Celebration]] As of the census<ref name="GR2">{{cite web|url=http://factfinder2.census.gov |website=[[United States Census Bureau]] |accessdate=2008-01-31 |title=American FactFinder |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130911234518/http://factfinder2.census.gov/ |archivedate=September 11, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref> of 2010, there were 7,427 people, 3,063 households, and 716 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 704.9 people per square mile (272.16.0/km²). There were 4,566 housing units at an average density of 102.4/sq mi (39.6/km²). The racial makeup of the CDP was 91.0% [[White American|white]] (with 81.9% of the population [[Non-Hispanic Whites|non-Hispanic white]]), 1.5% [[African American|black]], 3.2% [[Asian American|Asian]], 2.2% from [[Multiracial American|two or more races]] and 0.26% [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]]. [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanics or Latinos]] of any race were 11.2% of the population.
There were 3,063 households, out of which 32.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.0% were married couples living together, 4.5% had a female householder with no married spouse present, and 35.0% were non-families. 24.3% of all households were made up of individuals and 3.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.44 and the average family size was 2.96.
The age distribution was 25.6% under the age of 18, and 9.2% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 37 years. For every 100 females, there were 94.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.5 males.
The median income for a household in the CDP was $74,231, and the median income for a family was $92,334. Males had a median income of $51,250 versus $46,650 for females. The per-capita income for the CDP was $39,521, and 4.1% of the population lived below the [[poverty line]].
==Government== [[File:Osceola County Fire Station 72, Celebration.jpg|thumb|Osceola County Fire Station #72]] The area is organized under state law as a [[community development district]]. As a result, voting is restricted to local landowners. The largest landowners are entities controlled by [[The Walt Disney Company]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pittman|first1=Craig|title=Oh, Florida!: How America's Weirdest State Influences the Rest of the Country|date=5 July 2016|publisher=St Martins Press|isbn=1250071208}}</ref>
==City life==
===Downtown=== [[Image:022306-CelebrationFL11.jpg|thumb|225px|A view of downtown Market Street.]] Celebration Town Center contains shops, restaurants, and other commercial establishments as well as 106 residences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://celebrationtowncenter.com/ |title=Celebration Florida |publisher=Celebration Town Center |accessdate=2012-07-05}}</ref>
===Community=== Celebration has six Christian churches, one Jewish congregation, and one Hospital Ministry.<ref>"[http://www.celebration.fl.us/town-info/directory/worship/ Worship] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150810203539/http://www.celebration.fl.us/town-info/directory/worship/ |date=August 10, 2015 }}". ''Directory''. Retrieved on August 18, 2015.</ref>
===Commerce=== There are now more than five hundred registered companies<ref>"[http://www.sunbiz.org Sunbiz.org]" ''Division of Corporations – Florida Department of State''</ref> listed as doing business in the shopping plazas, small office complexes, and the Disney World office building park. This community holds the only Class A office buildings in [[Osceola County, Florida|Osceola County]].{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
===Villages=== [[Image:OSB - Celebration 33.jpg|thumb|225px|Low-density housing located in a primarily residential village.]]{{Advert|section|date=December 2016}} Celebration is separated into areas referred to as "villages." The main village, closest to downtown, is where the first homes were constructed. North Village, closest to U.S. 192, houses the Georgetown Condos as well as Acadia Estate Homes. East Village includes [[Roseville Corner]] and Aquila Loop. Lake Evalyn, generally considered its own area of Celebration but not quite its own village, includes a small lake where one can find a multitude of ducks, alligators, and the occasional river otter. South Village houses the Spring Park Loop estate homes and Heritage Hall. Additionally, Siena Condos complete the outer edge of South Village by Celebration Blvd. Mirasol includes condos with concierge service and a day spa. [[Artisan Park]] is at the end of Celebration Ave and houses condos, townhomes, single-family residences as well as a clubhouse consisting of a pool, gym, and restaurant.
===Events=== [[File:Celebration, Florida.jpg|thumb|A gathering in Celebration on [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]]]] Celebration hosts many events every year, including community-wide yard sales, an art show, an exotic car festival, an annual Radio Disney Holiday concert, an Oktoberfest Celebration, the "Great American Pie Festival" (televised on [[The Food Network]]),<ref>"[http://www.piecouncil.org/Events/GreatAmericanPieFestival/ Great American Pie Festival] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111014514/http://www.piecouncil.org/Events/GreatAmericanPieFestival/ |date=November 11, 2013 }}"</ref> a "Posh Pooch" festival, and downtown events for the Fall and Christmas seasons when autumn leaves and "snow" (small-scale soap flakes) are released into the Town Center. The community also hosts a large [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] fireworks celebration. The town events are organized on the Internet by the Community Calendar.<ref>"[http://www.celebration.fl.us/celebration-events/annual/ Community Calendar] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304073647/http://www.celebration.fl.us/celebration-events/annual/ |date=March 4, 2016 }}" ''Celebration Desktop''</ref>
==Civil suit== In 2016, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that Celebration Town Center condominium owners "are battling leaky roofs, balconies that have become separated from the sides of buildings and mold spreading in their walls. Their properties have become so dilapidated, they say, they're having trouble selling them."
An April 2016 civil suit seeks to force the Town Center Foundation, "which took control of part of Celebration in 2004, to pay for upward of $15 million to $20 million in repairs" which were deferred over ten years.<ref name="mold">{{cite web |title=Leaks and Mold Are Ruining the Disney Magic in Celebration, Florida |work=The Wall Street Journal |author=Laura Kusisto |date=November 15, 2016 |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/leaks-and-mold-are-ruining-the-disney-magic-in-celebration-florida-1479249246}}</ref>
== Transportation == 91% of residents who work outside their homes drive to work.<ref>{{cite triumph|page=215}}</ref>
The two main roads going through the center of the Celebration's downtown area are Market Street and Front Street. Other streets in Celebration include:
;Celebration Avenue: This is considered the main road in the town. The road stretches from [[U.S. Route 192|U.S. 192]] to Artisan Park where it ends in a [[traffic circle]]. Starting from U.S. 192 near the Disney Parks and the Celebration water tower, you can find a small shopping plaza. From there, Celebration Avenue passes the North Village, splits the Celebration golf course, winds through a few down-town shops and schools, and then proceeds into the parks and homes in the newer sections of Celebration. ;Celebration Boulevard: Celebration Boulevard has two sections. The most public section is an avenue parallel to [[Interstate 4|I-4]] that includes many commercial businesses and [[Celebration High School]]. The architecture on the street is mostly Celebration Modern style. This style reflects art [[Streamline Moderne]] and [[Art Deco]] influences with its sleek lines, sparse but effective ornamentation, and ample opportunities for individually expressive special features. The entire street is lined with two rows of [[Arecaceae|Washington Palms]]. The buildings on the street include sitting areas under the shade of trees and trellises along their frontage. The other section of Celebration Boulevard lies on the other side of the golf course, closer to the Celebration Water Tower in the North Village. Here, Celebration Boulevard is almost completely residential. In addition to the homes perched behind white picket fences, this section of Celebration Boulevard flows past the Georgetown condominiums, the community pool, and soccer fields. ;Celebration Place: Celebration Place nearly spans the gap between the two sections of Celebration Boulevard, except that its eastern end terminates at the Water Tower Plaza instead of at the entrance to North Village on the other side of [[Florida State Road 417|State Road 417]]. Celebration Place is a commercial road.
==Education== [[File:West Osceola Branch Library, Celebration.jpg|thumb|West Osceola Branch Library]] The [[School District of Osceola County, Florida]] operates public schools in Celebration.<ref>"[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/MapItDrawServlet?geo_id=16000US1211285&_bucket_id=50&tree_id=420&context=saff&_lang=en&_sse=on Celebration CDP, Florida]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}." [[U.S. Census Bureau]]. Retrieved on December 29, 2010.</ref> Celebration is zoned to the Celebration School for K-8.<ref>"[http://www.osceola.k12.fl.us/SchList/documents/0711.pdf Celebration School (K-8) Attendance Zone Boundary 2010/2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718172352/http://www.osceola.k12.fl.us/SchList/documents/0711.pdf |date=July 18, 2011 }}." [[School District of Osceola County, Florida]]. Retrieved on December 29, 2010.</ref> The school was and still partly is, using experimental education. This includes having many children, about 80, in one classroom, with three teachers.<ref>{{cite AV media |people= |date= October 24, 2018|title= Celebration Florida: Disney's Not So Perfect Town|trans-title= |medium= |language= |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e2e0-fLYNWo|access-date= November 12, 2018|archive-url= |archive-date= |format= |time= 3:36-3:56|location= |publisher= Rob Plays|id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }}</ref> [[Celebration High School]], located in the city, serves Celebration for grades 9–12.<ref>"[http://www.osceola.k12.fl.us/SchList/documents/0902.pdf Celebration High Attendance Zone Boundary 2010/2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718172409/http://www.osceola.k12.fl.us/SchList/documents/0902.pdf |date=July 18, 2011 }}." [[School District of Osceola County, Florida]]. Retrieved on December 29, 2010.</ref> There are private education options provided by the Montessori School of Celebration (K-8).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.celebrationmontessori.com|title= Montessori School of Celebration}}</ref> Private graduate education is available at [[Stetson University]] Celebration Campus.<ref>"[http://www2.setson.edu/celebration Stetson Celebration Office]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}"</ref> There are free classes offered at the community center by clubs for cooking, gardening, art, writing, and technology.
The [[Osceola Library System]] operates the West Osceola Branch Library in Celebration.<ref>"[http://www.osceolalibrary.org/hours.html Hours & Locations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125235902/http://osceolalibrary.org/hours.html |date=November 25, 2010 }}." [[Osceola Library System]]. Retrieved on December 29, 2010. Click map link, and "6070 W Irlo Bronson Memorial Hwy Kissimmee, FL 34747" will be displayed</ref>

The '''Collinsville Renewable Energy Promotion Act''' ({{USBill|113|H.R.|316}}; {{USPL|113|122}}) is a U.S. public law that was introduced into the [[113th United States Congress]], which passed in the [[United States House of Representatives]] on February 12, 2013. The bill allows the town of [[Canton, Connecticut]] to take over two lapsed licenses from the [[Federal Energy Regulatory Commission]] (FERC) in order to refurbish two old local dams. The dams would be used to produce [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric power]].
==Background== ''This summary is based largely on the summary provided by the [http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CRPT-113hrpt7/pdf/CRPT-113hrpt7.pdf House Report 113-7], a [[public domain]] source.''<ref name=housereport113-7>{{cite web |title=House Report 113-7 |url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CRPT-113hrpt7/pdf/CRPT-113hrpt7.pdf |publisher=United States Government Printing Office |accessdate=April 12, 2013}}</ref>
The Upper and Lower Collinsville [[Dam]]s on the [[Farmington River]] were built to provide [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric power]] to an [[Axe|ax]] factory, which was shut down in 1966. The dams have not produced power since that time, but continue to block upstream fish passage.
On February 23, 2001, FERC issued original licenses to Summit Hydropower to redevelop hydroelectric power capacity at these dams. The Upper Collinsville Dam project was to have a generation capacity of 373 [[Watt|kilowatts]], while the Lower Dam was to have a capacity of 920 kilowatts. As part of this licensing process, an environmental assessment was completed. The licenses required Summit to commence project construction within two years from the issuance of the licenses.
Section 13 of the [[Federal Power Act]] requires licensees to commence construction of hydroelectric projects within the time fixed in the license, which shall be no more than two years from the issuance of the license, and authorizes the Commission to issue one extension of the deadline, for no more than two years.
On November 26, 2002, FERC granted Summit a two-year extension to commence project construction at both sites, moving the deadline to February 23, 2005. Because construction did not commence by that date, the Commission sent Summit a notice of probable termination of the licenses on November 2, 2007. Summit did not respond to the notice. FERC terminated the licenses on December 4, 2007. Summit did not seek rehearing of the termination order.
The town of [[Canton, Connecticut]] intends to proceed with the two hydroelectric projects that Summit originally had proposed. On January 9, 2009, FERC granted the town a preliminary permit to undertake the necessary feasibility studies. The town has stated that it intends to pursue [[Low Impact Hydropower Institute]] certification for the projects and to provide for [[Fish ladder|fish passage]].
Identical legislation passed the House of Representatives in both the [[111th United States Congress|111th]] and [[112th United States Congress|112th Congresses]] as H.R. 4451 and H.R. 5625, respectively. H.R. 4451 was agreed to in the House by [[voice vote]], under [[Suspension of the rules in the United States Congress|suspension of the rules]], on June 16, 2010. H.R. 5625 passed the House by voice vote, under suspension of the rules, on June 26, 2012.
==Provisions/Elements of the bill== ''This summary is based largely on the summary provided by the [[Congressional Research Service]], a [[public domain]] source.''<ref name=316sum>{{cite web |title=H.R 316 – 113th Congress |url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/316 |publisher=United States Congress |accessdate=April 12, 2013}}</ref>
The Collinsville Renewable Energy Promotion Act would authorize the [[Federal Energy Regulatory Commission]] (FERC) to:<ref name="316sum" /> :(1) reinstate the license for either or each of the projects numbered 10822 and 10823, and :(2) extend for two years after the date on which either or each such project is reinstated the time period during which the licensee must commence project construction.
The Collinsville Renewable Energy Promotion Act also directs the FERC to:<ref name="316sum" /> :(1) transfer the reinstated licenses to the town of [[Canton, Connecticut]], if it reinstates them and extends the time period during which the licensee is required to commence project construction; and :(2) complete an environmental assessment for the projects and update the environmental analysis performed during the licensing process.
Finally, the Collinsville Renewable Energy Promotion Act sets a deadline for the FERC to:<ref name="316sum" /> :(1) reach a final decision concerning the projects, and :(2) complete the license transfer if it decides to reinstate either or both licenses.
The Collinsville Renewable Energy Promotion Act provides a variety of exemptions from provisions of the [[Federal Power Act]] to the two projects listed in the bill.<ref name=316text>{{cite web |title=H.R. 316 – Text |url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/316/text |publisher=United States Congress |accessdate=April 12, 2013}}</ref>
==Procedural history== The bill was introduced to the House by [[Elizabeth Esty|Rep. Elizabeth Esty (D-CT)]] on January 18, 2013.<ref name="316sum" /> It was referred to the [[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce]] and the [[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Energy and Power]]. The bill had no co-sponsors and was not amended while in the House of Representatives.<ref name="316sum" /> On February 12, 2013, the bill was passed under a motion to [[Suspension of the rules in the United States Congress|suspend the rules]] with a [[voice vote]]. This procedure typically indicates that a bill is broadly non-controversial. The bill was freshman Representative Esty's first bill in Congress.<ref>{{cite news |title=Elizabeth Esty's first bill, reintroduced Collinsville dams legislation, passes House |url=http://www.foothillsmediagroup.com/articles/2013/02/18/canton/news/doc51228c29d578e656011125.txt |accessdate=April 12, 2013 |newspaper=The Avon News |date=February 18, 2013}}</ref>
The bill was received by the [[United States Senate]] on February 13, 2013 and then referred to the [[United States Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources]]. The Senate passed the bill by [[unanimous consent]] on May 22, 2014 after making an amendment in the nature of a substitute.<ref name=316allactions>{{cite web |title=H.R. 316 – All Actions |url=https://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/316/all-actions |publisher=United States Congress |accessdate=June 23, 2014}}</ref>
The House voted on June 23, 2014 to agree to the Senate's amendment of the bill. The vote was 379-3 in [https://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/316/actions Roll Call Vote 340].<ref name="316allactions" /> President [[Barack Obama]] signed the bill into law on June 30, 2014.
==Public perception== The bill received very little attention from the national press. It was briefly covered in local media of Canton, Connecticut and the surrounding areas. One op-ed writer was strongly opposed to the bill, claiming that it was locally known as the "Collinsville White Elephant Act."<ref name=opedMar4>{{cite news |last=Budnick |first=Chris |title=Avon Letters to the Editor |url=http://www.foothillsmediagroup.com/articles/2013/03/04/opinion/doc513502478cd78681754770.txt?viewmode=fullstory |accessdate=April 12, 2013 |newspaper=The Avon News |date=March 4, 2013}}</ref> The op-ed writer argued that rather than being a win-win situation, the new power plants would only serve to increase the electricity bills of local residents and provide additional revenue for the local government (potentially for them to misspend).<ref name="opedMar4" /> He based this assessment on existing state electricity laws and problems associated with [[net metering]].

{{Infobox religious building |image=DITIB-Zentralmoschee Köln - April 2015-7489.jpg |caption=Cologne Mosque in April 2015 |building_name=Cologne Central Mosque |location=[[Ehrenfeld, Cologne|Ehrenfeld]], [[Cologne]]
[[Germany]] |geo={{coord|50|56|44|N|6|55|42|E|region:DE-NW_type:landmark_source:dewiki}} |religious_affiliation=[[Sunni Islam]] |website=[http://www.ditib.de www.ditib.de/] |architect=[[:de:wp:Paul Böhm|Paul Böhm]] |architecture_type=Mosque |architecture_style=[[Modern architecture|Modern]] |year_completed=2017 |construction_cost= [[Euro|€]]17-20 million |capacity= |dome_quantity= |minaret_quantity= }} The '''Cologne Central Mosque''' ({{lang-de|DITIB-Zentralmoschee Köln}}, {{lang-tr|Merkez-Camii}}) is a building commissioned by [[Islam in Germany|German Muslims]] of the Organization [[DITIB]] for a large, representative ''Zentralmoschee'' (central mosque){{cite web |url=http://www.boehmarchitektur.de/deutsch/hochbau/hochbau_zentralmoschee.html |title=ZENTRALMOSCHEE KÖLN |accessdate=2007-09-16 |work= |last=Böhm |first=Plul |language=german}} ([https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=de&u=http://www.boehmarchitektur.de/deutsch/hochbau/hochbau_zentralmoschee.html&sa=X&oi=translate&resnum=1&ct=result&prev=/search%3Fq%3Dhttp://www.boehmarchitektur.de/deutsch/hochbau/hochbau_zentralmoschee.html%26hl%3Den English translation]) in Cologne, Germany. This mosque is being inaugurated by Turkish President [[Erdogan]]. After controversy, the project won the approval of Cologne's city council.Jenkner, Carolyn. "[http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/0,1518,575170,00.html Go-Ahead for Germany's Biggest Mosque]," ''[[Spiegel Online]]''. August 29, 2008. The mosque is designed in [[Ottoman Empire|non-Ottoman]] architectural style, with glass walls, two minarets and a dome. The mosque is proposed to have a bazaar as well as other secular areas intended for interfaith interactions. As the mosque will be one of [https://theislamicinformation.com/erdogan-biggest-mosque-europe/ Europe's biggest mosques], and the largest mosque in Germany,{{cite news|title=How Recep Tayyip Erdogan seduces Turkish migrants in Europe|url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21727921-big-diaspora-complicates-european-relations-turkey-how-recep-tayyip-erdogan-seduces|accessdate=2 September 2017|work=[[The Economist]]|date=31 August 2017}} it has been criticized for its size, particularly the height of the minarets. == Design == The {{convert|48000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} mosque cost £15–20 million to build,Harry de Quetteville. "[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/06/25/wger125.xml Huge mosque stirs protests in Cologne]". ''Telegraph'', June 26, 2007. aiming to house 2,000 to 4,000 worshippers.Grieshaber, Kirsten.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/04/AR2007070400814.html Tempers flare in German mosque dispute]. Associated Press, July 4, 2007.{{cite news|url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/world/story/0,,2126622,00.html|title=Mosque stirs racial passion in Germany|last=Burke|first=Jason | work=The Guardian | location=London | date=July 15, 2007 | accessdate=April 30, 2010}} The mosque is funded by [[Diyanet İşleri Türk İslam Birliği]] (DITIB), a branch of the [[Turkey|Turkish]] government's religious affairs authority,[http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/detaylar.do?load=detay&link=115950 Turks’ plans to build mosque in Germany divides religions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930211236/http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/detaylar.do?load=detay&link=115950 |date=2007-09-30 }}. Today's Zaman. Retrieved July 8, 2007 bank loans, and donations from 884 Muslim associations. Cologne's St. Theodore Catholic Church has also decided to fundraise for the mosque.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Catholic church collects money for mosque |url=http://www.expatica.com/actual/article.asp?subchannel_id=26&story_id=37774 |work= |publisher=Expatica |date=March 16, 2007 |accessdate=2007-12-02 }} The architects of the mosque are [[Gottfried Böhm]] and his son Paul Böhm,{{cite news|first=|last=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=Mosque project stirs concerns about the integration of Islam in Germany|url=http://www.freep.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070822/NEWS07/708220432/1001/NEWS|work=|publisher=[[Detroit Free Press]]|date=August 22, 2007|accessdate=2007-09-16|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018010935/http://www.freep.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20070822%2FNEWS07%2F708220432%2F1001%2FNEWS|archivedate=October 18, 2007|deadurl=yes|df=}} who specializes in building churches. The mosque is not in the [[Ottoman architecture]] style. It has a concrete and glass dome, and two 55 meter high [[minaret]]s. The mosque has the [[bazaar]] and entrance on the ground floor, lecture halls in the basement, the prayer area on the upper floor and include a Muslim library. A well is placed in the centre to connect the two levels and create a pleasant atmosphere. The mosque consists of flat-like wall screens which form a dome in the centre. It also has glass walls, which according to DITIB spokesman Alboga give visitors a feeling of openness. According to the architect, openness is further enhanced by an inviting staircase from the street.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Muslims Should Not Try to Hide |url=http://www.qantara.de/webcom/show_article.php/_c-478/_nr-446/i.html?PHPSESSID=5 |work= |publisher=Qantara |date=October 5, 2006 |accessdate=2007-12-02 }} The developers have required that the secular areas of the mosque (e.g. the restaurant, event halls and stores) be open to people of all religions. A plan welcomed by then mayor of Cologne [[Fritz Schramma]] to build shorter minarets was dropped after the architects said the plan would leave the minarets out of proportion with the rest of the building and surrounding structures.{{cite web|url=http://www.expatica.com/de/articles/news/plans-to-lower-height-of-cologne-mosque-dropped--43139.html|title=Plans to lower height of Cologne mosque dropped|publisher=expatica.com|accessdate=2008-12-10}} == Opening == The inauguration of the mosque was controversial as the [[Turkish-Islamic Union for Religious Affairs]] neglected to invite mayor of Cologne [[Henriette Reker]] to the event. The failure to invite officials of Cologne municipality was interpreted as the mosque representing a growing Turkish parallel society in Germany and lacking respect for German institutions. President of Turkey [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] attended and held a speech at the event.{{Cite news|url=http://www.faz.net/1.5812065|title=Kölner Oberbürgermeisterin: Reker beklagt mangelnden Respekt von Ditib|last=Burger|first=Reiner|work=FAZ.NET|access-date=2018-10-12|language=de|issn=0174-4909}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article181682982/Erdogan-in-Koeln-Reker-wirft-Ditib-mangelnden-Respekt-vor.html|title=Erdogan in Köln: Reker wirft Ditib mangelnden Respekt vor|last=Frigelj|first=Kristian|date=2018-09-27|work=DIE WELT|access-date=2018-10-12}} == Controversy == The project has been opposed by author [[Ralph Giordano (writer)|Ralph Giordano]], right-wingers, Jörg Uckermann, then local district's deputy mayor, has criticized the project saying that "We don't want to build a Turkish ghetto in Ehrenfeld. I know about [[Londonistan]] and I don't want that here." Markus Wiener of local activist group [[Pro Germany Citizens' Movement#Pro Cologne Citizen's Movement|Pro Cologne]],{{cite book |last1= Killguss |first1=Hans-Peter |last2=Peters|first2=Jürgen|last3=Häusler |first3=Alexander |editor-first=Alexander |editor-last=Häusler |title= Rechtspopulismus als "Bürgerbewegung": Kampagnen gegen Islam und Moscheebau und kommunale Gegenstrategien |trans-title=|url= |format= |date= |year= 2008 |month= |origyear= |publisher=VS Verlag für Sozialwissenschaften |location=Wiesbaden |language= |isbn=978-3-531-91119-9 |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages=55–71, S. 55 |trans-chapter=|chapter=PRO KÖLN – Entstehung und Aktivitäten |chapterurl=http://www.springerlink.com/content/ux568174083u714j/fulltext.pdf }}.
{{cite book |last=Häusler |first=Alexander |editor1-first=Alexander |editor1-last=Häusler |title= Rechtspopulismus als "Bürgerbewegung": Kampagnen gegen Islam und Moscheebau und kommunale Gegenstrategien |trans-title=|url= |format= |date= |year= 2008 |month= |origyear= |publisher=VS Verlag für Sozialwissenschaften |location=Wiesbaden |language= |isbn=978-3-531-91119-9 |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages=88–93, S. 90 [90] |trans-chapter=|chapter=Politische Programmatik von PRO NRW |chapterurl=http://www.springerlink.com/content/k2624445tk67j022/fulltext.pdf }} expressed his fear that the Cologne mosque will empower the Muslim population too much.{{cite news |first= Emily |last= Harris |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Two Mosques, Two Different Reactions in Germany |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=15043704 |work= |publisher=National Public Radio |date=October 11, 2007 |accessdate=2007-12-02 }} On June 16, 2007, 200 people gathered in a protest organized by Pro Cologne against the mosque including representatives from the [[Austrian Freedom Party]] and the Belgian [[Vlaams Belang]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/05/world/europe/05cologne.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all Germans Split Over a Mosque and the Role of Islam]. New York Times Then district deputy mayor Uckermann seconded that he thinks many residents reject the mosque because they believe that Cologne is a “Christian city”.''[http://www.islamicboard.com/815459-post1.html Mosque project stirs concerns about the integration of Islam in Germany]''. [[Chicago Tribune]]. August 22, 2007. The prominent author [[Ralph Giordano (writer)|Ralph Giordano]] stated that he opposed the project as the mosque would be “an expression of the creeping [[Islamization]] of our land”, a “declaration of war”, and that he wouldn't want to see women wearing headscarfs on German streets, likening their appearance to “human penguins”. [[Henryk M. Broder]], a journalist, disagrees with Giordano's metaphor but said that “A mosque is more than a church or a synagogue. It is a political statement.” Giordano's remarks have turned the local dispute into a national debate about the place of [[Islam in Germany]]. and other prominent Germans criticized the project as well. District mayor Uckermann stated that Giordano's comments “broke down the wall. Before if you criticised this monstrous mosque you were a [[Nazi]]. But we have a problem with the integration of Muslims. It's a question of language and culture.” Uckermann left the conservative CDU for right-wing Pro Cologne in 2008 after being voted out of office as the district's deputy mayor and reportedly facing party exclusion.{{cite web|url = http://www.ksta.de/html/artikel/1209912089325.shtml|archive-url = https://archive.is/20120803104624/http://www.ksta.de/html/artikel/1209912089325.shtml|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 3 August 2012|title = Jörg Uckermann: Eine zweifelhafte Karriere|first = Detlef|last = Schmalenberg|date = 20 May 2008|work = www.ksta.de|publisher = [[Kölner Stadt-Anzeiger]]|language = German|trans-title = Jörg Uckermann: a dubious career|accessdate = 29 October 2011}}[[File:Ditib-Zentralmoschee Köln - April 2011 (3561-63).jpg|thumb|The state of construction of the Cologne Mosque in April 2011|277x277px]]The city's official for integration Marlis Bredehorst stated that "it is important that the Muslims here get dignified houses of prayer" and added that "two hundred years ago, the Protestants had to pray secretively in Catholic Cologne [...] that is something we can't imagine anymore today." The city's mayor, [[Fritz Schramma]], who supports the project said that “For me, it is self-evident that the Muslims need to have a prestigious place of worship, but it bothers me when people have lived here for 35 years and they don’t speak a single word of German.” Christian leaders have taken similarly ambivalent stances: the Catholic Church has long supported the project, though recently Cardinal [[Joachim Meisner]], Archbishop of Cologne, has been more cautious: when asked if he was afraid of the mosque, he said, “I don't want to say I'm afraid, but I have an uneasy feeling.”''[http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/07/03/news/cologne.php Effort to build a large mosque rattles some in Cologne]''. International Herald Tribune He also stated that Turkey should allow its Christian minorities equivalent rights. He said the mosque would change the skyline of Cologne. [[Wolfgang Huber]], Germany's top Protestant bishop, criticized the “male domination” he saw in Islam and said Muslims should be able to convert to Christianity without fearing reprisals and the penalty of death. Public opinion seems “guardedly supportive, with a majority of residents saying they favor it”. A poll taken by a local newspaper among 500 Cologne residents showed that the project is supported by 63%, of whom 27% want its size to be reduced.Omniquest: [http://www.ksta.de/ks/images/mdsLink/umfrage_moschee.pdf Neubau einer Zentralmoschee in Ehrenfeld] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928104945/http://www.ksta.de/ks/images/mdsLink/umfrage_moschee.pdf |date=2011-09-28 }} ([[PDF]]), published ''Kölner Stadtanzeiger'', Juni 19, 2007 A protest planned by Pro Cologne for September 20, 2008 was canceled by police at the last minute in the interest of public safety, after clashes between police and protestors.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7627047.stm |title=Street clashes erupt in Germany |publisher=BBC|date=20 September 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-31}}{{cite news |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gbiH7ZVJQrR07iXn160OBd63xnNQ |title=German citizens protest against anti-Islam congress in Cologne |publisher=Afp.google.com |date=Sep 20, 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080929101150/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gbiH7ZVJQrR07iXn160OBd63xnNQ |archivedate=2008-09-29 |df= }} On August 28, 2008, the [[Cologne City Hall|Cologne City Council]] voted to approve the construction of the mosque. this position was taken by all parties except the [[Christian Democratic Union (Germany)|Christian democrats]] (CDU). Outside the hall, a group of 30 protesters demonstrated against the approval, while 100 demonstrated in favor of it. The Cologne mosque project has been contrasted with a less controversial project in [[Duisburg]], Germany: in Duisburg, there was co-operation and good communication from an early stage between German politicians, church and community leaders and the developers of the mosque.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Constructing conflict |url=http://www.economist.com/world/international/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9725332 |work= |publisher=[[The Economist]] |date=August 30, 2007 |accessdate=2007-12-02 }} == See also == {{Portal|Islam}} * [[Controversies related to Islam and Muslims]] * [[List of mosques in Germany]] == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{Commons category|DITIB-Zentralmoschee Köln}} * {{official|http://www.zentralmoschee-koeln.de/}} * {{structurae|s0043405}} * Çalışkan, Burcu: [http://Die%20Akte%20des%20medialen%20Islam%20–%20Moscheenboom%20in%20Deutschland.%20Ein%20Aufstieg%20des%20Homo%20Islamicus?%20Oder:%20Die%20Einbürgerung%20des%20Islams.%20Eine%20diskursanalytische%20und%20kommunikationswissenschaftliche%20Untersuchung%20des%20Moscheenstreits%20in%20Köln-Ehrenfeld.%202010. Die Akte des medialen Islam – Moscheenboom in Deutschland. Ein Aufstieg des Homo Islamicus? Oder: Die Einbürgerung des Islams. Eine diskursanalytische und kommunikationswissenschaftliche Untersuchung des Moscheenstreits in Köln-Ehrenfeld. 2010.] {{good article}} [[Category:Mosques in Germany]] [[Category:Mosque-related controversies in Europe]] [[Category:Religion and politics]] [[Category:Places of worship in Cologne]] [[Category:Ehrenfeld, Cologne]] [[Category:Buildings and structures under construction in Germany]]

[[Left-wing nationalism]] |national = |country = Spain |international = |european = |europarl = |colors = [[Red]], [[White]] |website = [http://www.ehak.org/ www.ehak.org] |footnotes = }} The '''Communist Party of the Basque Homelands''' ({{lang-eu|Euskal Herrialdeetako Alderdi Komunista}}, '''EHAK'''; {{lang-es|Partido Comunista de las Tierras Vascas}}, '''PCTV''') was a [[communist]] [[Basque separatist]] party in the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], [[Spain]]. The party was outlawed by the [[Spanish Supreme Court]] after it was judicially proven to be part of [[Batasuna]] and, ultimately, [[ETA (separatist group)|ETA]]. ==History== EHAK was legally registered for the first time in 2002 but had no known activity until 2005, remaining inactive during these years. In this year, within weeks of the [[Basque parliamentary election, 2005|regional Basque election]] EHAK suddenly rose to national prominence when it publicly announced that it would assume the program of the banned [[abertzale]] lists of [[Aukera Guztiak]] and [[Batasuna]]. EHAK was then widely considered to be a proxy to circumvent the recent ruling which had outlawed Batasuna. Like Batasuna, their representatives refused to explicitly condemn the [[ETA (separatist group)|ETA]] attacks, being the only important political party not to do so in the Basque Country and Spain. Batasuna representatives asked their supporters to vote for EHAK, which obtained 150,188 votes (12.5%), entering the [[Basque Parliament]] with nine seats.{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/comunes/2005/eleccionesvascas/ |title=Elecciones vascas 2005 |publisher=El Pais |date=2009-01-02 |accessdate=2010-04-17}} The [[People's Party (Spain)|People's Party]] requested that the Spanish government conducted investigations to ban EHAK too, though the initially State Legal Service (''Abogacía General del Estado'') and the Attorney General's Office (''Fiscalía General del Estado'') found no evidence to support legal actions against the party. {{Politics of Basque Country (autonomous community)}} ==Outlawing== [[File:Ehak.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Election poster of EHAK-PCTV with a painted portrait of the communist leader [[Lenin]].]] On 18 September 2008 the party was outlawed by the [[Spanish Supreme Court]]. According to the legal inquiry, EHAK was "instrumental in continuing the illegal action designed by ETA/Ekin/Batasuna", rapidly losing its autonomy to replace Batasuna's role in the institutional front of ETA's activities.{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Procesados/cargos/PCTV/pertenecer/ETA/elpepunac/20090718elpepinac_12/Tes |title=El Pais 18 July 2007 |publisher=Elpais.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-17}} Batasuna got, via EHAK, 837,000 [[euro]]s corresponding to the public funding given to political parties with parliamentary representation;{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Procesados/cargos/PCTV/pertenecer/ETA/elpepunac/20090718elpepinac_12/Tes |title=Procesados cinco cargos del PCTV por pertenecer a ETA · ELPAÍS.com |publisher=Elpais.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-17}} with no less than 34 Batasuna members (including some of their top officers) were hired by EHAK and paid with this public funding.{{cite web|author=D. Martínez |url=http://www.abc.es/20090718/nacional-terrorismo/batasuna-pctv-como-cobertura-20090718.html |title=ABC 18 July 2007 |publisher=Abc.es |date= |accessdate=2010-04-17}} In the end, according to the judicial inquiry, EHAK followed Batasuna's instructions to the point that there wasn't any difference.{{cite web|author=D. Martínez |url=http://www.abc.es/20090718/nacional-terrorismo/batasuna-pctv-como-cobertura-20090718.html |title=ABC |publisher=Abc.es |date= |accessdate=2010-04-17}} On 4 August 2009 the judge [[Baltasar Garzón]] announced his intention to put a number of PCTV members on trial for ETA membership. Among them were two former Basque parliament deputies Karmele Berasategi and Nekane Erauskin; the party president Juan Carlos Ramos and the two party treasurers Jesús María Aguirre and Sonia Jacinto.{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Procesadas/ex/diputadas/PCTV/ser/ETA/elpepunac/20090804elpepinac_12/Tes |title=El Pais 4 August 2009 |language=Spanish |publisher=Elpais.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-17}} == Notes == {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{es icon}} [http://www.mundurat.net/ehk/index_cas.html EHAK Official web page] [[Category:Political parties established in 2002]] [[Category:Communist parties in the Basque Country]] [[Category:Banned communist parties]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Spain]] [[Category:Communist parties in Spain]] [[Category:Banned secessionist parties]] [[Category:Banned political parties in the Basque Country]] {{Spain-party-stub}} {{Europe-communist-party-stub}}

{{dictdef}} '''Damning with faint praise''' is an [[English idiom]], expressing [[oxymoron]]ically that half-hearted or insincere praise may act as oblique criticism or condemnation.<ref>Ichikawa, Sanki. (1964). ''The Kenkyusha Dictionary of Current English Idioms,'' pp. 153–154.</ref><ref name="ammer153">Ammer, Christine. (2001). [https://books.google.com/books?id=9re1vfFh04sC&pg=PA153&dq= ''The American Heritage Dictionary of Idioms,'' p. 153.]</ref>
==History of the term== The concept can be found in the work of the Hellenistic [[sophist]] and [[philosopher]] [[Favorinus]] (c. 110 AD) who observed that faint and half-hearted praise was more harmful than loud and persistent abuse.<ref>Walsh, William Shepard. (1908). [https://books.google.com/books?id=xAQoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA586&dq= ''The International Encyclopedia of Prose and Poetical Quotations from the Literature of the World,'' p. 586], citing [[Aulus Gellius]], ''Noctes Atticae.'' xi, 3, 1.</ref>
The explicit phrasing of the modern English idiomic expression was first published by [[Alexander Pope]] in his 1734 poem, "[[Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot]]" in ''Prologue to the Satires.''<ref>Walsh, William Shepard. (1909). [https://books.google.com/books?id=hrJkAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA211&dq= ''Handy-book of Literary Curiosities,'' p. 211.]</ref> ::Damn with faint praise, assent with civil leer, ::And without sneering, teach the rest to sneer; ::Willing to wound, and yet afraid to strike, ::Just hint a fault, and hesitate dislike. ::::— "Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot" by Alexander Pope (1688–1744)<ref>Pope, Alexander. (1901) [https://books.google.com/books?id=xXciKdpaH0oC&printsec=frontcover&dq= ''The Rape of the Lock: An Essay on Man and Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot,'' p. 97;] n.b., ''see'' line 201 in "Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot."</ref>
According to William Shepard Walsh, "There is a faint anticipation in [[William Wycherley]]'s 'Double Dealer,' 'and libels everybody with dull praise,' But a closer parallel is in [[Phineas Fletcher]], —" ::When needs he must, yet faintly then he praises, ::Somewhat the deed, much more the means he raises: ::So marreth what he makes, and praising most, dispraises. ::::— "The Purple Island" by Phineas Fletcher<ref>Walsh, William Shepard, ''Handy-book of Literary Curiosities,''[https://books.google.com/books?id=hrJkAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA211&dq= pp. 211–212; n.b., ''see'' Canto vii in "The Purple Island."]</ref>
== Examples == * 2009, [http://www.smh.com.au/news/technology/biztech/battle-to-outgun-wikipedia-and-google/2009/01/22/1232471469973.html?page=2 interview] with [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] president [[Jorge Cauz]] in the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'': :". . . [Cauz] said a big problem was that '''many users considered Wikipedia to be 'fine' or 'good enough''''." * 1917, [[w:Lucy Maud Montgomery|Lucy Maud Montgomery]], "The Alpine Path: The Story Of My Career": :"They wrote that “'''Our readers report that they find some merit in your story, but not enough to warrant its acceptance'''.” * 2010, [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/17/opinion/17dowd.html The Way They Were], ''[[The New York Times]]'': :". . . when [George] W. [Bush] could avoid it no longer, he mentioned Vice [President Dick Cheney], damning with faint praise: “'''Dick Cheney’s advice was consistent and strong'''.”"
==See also== *[[Backhanded compliment#Backhanded compliment|Backhanded compliment]] *[[Polite fiction]] *[[Sarcasm]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Sources== * Ammer, Christine. (1997). ''The American Heritage Dictionary of Idioms.'' New York: [[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]]. {{ISBN|978-0-395-72774-4}}; {{OCLC|228041670}} * Browne, William Hardcastle. (1900). ''Odd Derivations of Words, Phrases, Slang, Synonyms and Proverbs.'' Philadelphia: Arnold. {{OCLC|23900443}} * Hirsch, Eric Donald Hirsch, Joseph F. Kett and James S. Trefil. (2002). ''The New Dictionary of Cultural Literacy.'' Boston: [[Houghton Mifflin]]. {{ISBN|978-0-618-22647-4}}; {{ISBN|978-0-9657664-3-2}}; {{OCLC|50166721}} * Ichikawa, Sanki. (1964). ''The Kenkyusha Dictionary of Current English Idioms.'' Tokyo: Kenkyusha. {{OCLC|5056712}} * Pope, Alexander and Henry Walcott Boynton. (1901). ''The Rape of the Lock. An essay on Man and Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot.'' Boston: Houghton, Mifflin Co. {{OCLC|3147633}} * Walsh, William Shepard. (1892). ''Handy-book of Literary Curiosities.'' Philadelphia: [[J. B. Lippincott & Co.|Lippincott]].{{OCLC|247190584}} * __________. (1908). ''The International Encyclopedia of Prose and Poetical Quotations from the Literature of the World.'' Toronto: C. Clark. {{OCLC|22391024}}
==External links== {{wiktionary|damn with faint praise}} *Alexander Pope. [http://ethnicity.rutgers.edu/~jlynch/Texts/arbuthnot.html "Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot," annotated text of the poem]

'''Democratic Left Scotland''' is the continuation in Scotland of [[Democratic Left (United Kingdom)|Democratic Left]], the organisation formed when the [[Communist Party of Great Britain]] was dissolved in 1991. DLS was founded in May 1998.<ref>{{cite book|last=Laybourn|first=Keith|title=Marxism in Britain: dissent, decline and re-emergence 1945-c.2000|publisher=Taylor & Francis|date=2006|series=Volume 3 of Routledge studies in modern British history|isbn=0-415-32287-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X4_q46RCeJQC&pg=PA153}}</ref>
While DLS's sister organisation in England and Wales later renamed itself the [[New Politics Network]] and has since merged into the think tank [[Unlock Democracy]], DLS is still active as part of the left. It publishes an occasional magazine, ''Perspectives''.
The organisation's slogan is ''"There's more to politics than parties"'', but some of its members do participate in other parties, such as the [[Scottish Socialist Party]] and [[Scottish Green Party]], including [[Mark Ballard]], former Green Party [[Member of the Scottish Parliament]] for [[Lothians]]. Two City of Edinburgh councillors are members of DLS.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * http://www.democraticleftscotland.org.uk/

'''Double salary saga''' is the name given by media outlets to a [[political scandal]] in [[Ghana]]. In 2018, some members of the [[John Mahama]] administration who were ministers or deputy ministers and doubled as members of parliament were alleged to have received double salaries during their term in office.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myjoyonline.com/politics/2018/April-19th/double-salary-saga-parliament-urges-calm.php|title=Double salary saga: Parliament urges calm|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Double-salary-saga-Ex-Ministers-accounts-revealed-652951|title=Double salary saga: Ex-Ministers' accounts revealed|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> The law however requires such officials to choose to receive salary either as a minister or a member of parliament<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myjoyonline.com/politics/2018/April-18th/witch-hunting-crusaders-admitted-to-taking-double-salaries-majority-leader.php|title=Witch-hunting crusaders admitted to taking double salaries- Majority Leader|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}{{Ghana-stub}} [[Category:Corruption in Ghana]] [[Category:Political scandals]]

[https://www.bundespolizei.de/Web/DE/_Home/home_node.html www.bundespolizei.de] ([[German language|German]]) | footnotes = }} The '''Federal Police''' ('''''Bundespolizei''''' or '''BPOL''') is a (primarily) uniformed [[Federal police|federal police force]] in [[Germany]]. It is subordinate to the [[Federal Ministry of the Interior (Germany)|Federal Ministry of the Interior]] (''Bundesministerium des Innern (BMI)'').OSCE Entry on BPOL http://polis.osce.org/countries/details.php?item_id=17#Country_Profile_Section_211 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524060329/http://polis.osce.org/countries/details.php?item_id=17 |date=2009-05-24 }} Ordinary police forces, meanwhile, are under the administration of the individual German states (''[[States of Germany|Bundesländer]]'') and are known as the ''[[Landespolizei]]''. The ''Bundespolizei'' was formerly known as the ''[[Bundesgrenzschutz]]'' (BGS) ("Federal Border Guard"), which had a more restricted role. Prior to 1994 BGS members also had military combatant status due to their historical foundation and border-guard role in West Germany. In July 2005 the law renaming the BGS as the BPOL was enacted. ==Missions== {{Unreferenced section|date=October 2017}} The BPOL has the following missions: * Border security (''Grenzpolizei'' or [[Grepo]]), to include passport control (only at borders with non-EU member countries prior to September 2015) and the provision of [[German Federal Coast Guard|coast guard]] services along Germany's {{convert|700|km|mi|abbr=on}} of coastline. * Protection of [[federal government|federal]] buildings such as Schloss Bellevue, the residence of the German [[President of Germany|Bundespräsident]]; they also protect the two highest German courts, both in [[Karlsruhe]]: ** The [[Federal Constitutional Court]] (''Bundesverfassungsgericht'') and ** The [[Federal Court of Justice]] (''Bundesgerichtshof'') * Providing the federal government's [[Bereitschaftspolizei|mobile response force]] for internal security events. * Providing transportation security at [[international airport]]s and on German railways. * Providing counter-[[terrorism]] forces ([[GSG 9]]). * Providing [[Air Marshal (civil aviation)|air (or sky) marshals]]. * Supporting international police missions for the [[United Nations]] and EU in [[Kosovo]], [[Sudan]], [[Liberia]], [[Afghanistan]], [[Gaza Strip]], [[Moldova]] and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. * Providing in-house security for some German embassies. * Providing rescue [[helicopter]] service. [[File:Kontrolle der Bundespolizei.JPG|thumbnail|Stop and search on a motorway: BPOL inspecting a [[Coach (bus)|bus]] at a [[rest stop]] off [[Bundesautobahn 9]].]] The ''Bundespolizei'' can also be used to reinforce [[landespolizei|state police]] if requested by a state ''(Land)'' government. The BPOL maintains these reserve forces to deal with major demonstrations, disturbances or emergencies, supplementing the capabilities of the [[Bereitschaftspolizei|State Operational Support Units]]. Several highly trained detachments are available for crisis situations requiring [[Armored car (military)|armored car]]s, [[water cannon]] or other special equipment. BPOL has investigators conduct criminal investigations only within its jurisdiction; otherwise the cases are referred to the appropriate state police force or to the federal criminal investigative agency, the [[Federal Criminal Police Office (Germany)|Federal Criminal Police]] (''Bundeskriminalamt'', BKA). In addition, the ''Bundespolizei'' cooperates closely with German state executive authorities, such as prosecutor's offices (''[[Staatsanwaltschaft]]'') in pursuing criminal investigations. ===Restoration of border control tasking on all borders (2015)=== On the night of 13 September 2015 Germany unilaterally reintroduced [[border controls]], under emergency provisions of the [[Schengen Agreement]], due to the [[European migrant crisis|2015 European migrant crisis]] overwhelming Germany's available resources, law enforcement and otherwise. The nominally temporary border controls were initially put in place just on the border with Austria, but by the following day (Monday 14 September 2015) they were being put in place at all borders with fellow EU members. The same day, Austria and other EU members who were part of the [[Schengen Area]] began to put in place their own border controls (again meant to be temporary) in response to Germany's actions. The new German border controls are to be primarily enforced both by the various ''[[Landespolizei]]'' of those German states that adjoin external borders, and in particular by the ''Bundespolizei''. ==Strength== The ''Bundespolizei'' consists of around 40,000 personnel: *30,000 are fully trained police officers. **21,000 provide border, railway and aviation security. **6,000 serve in the [[Bereitschaftspolizei|Alert Police]]. **3,000 serve in the following special units: *** The Central Office for Communications and Information. *** [[GSG 9]]. *** The Aviation Wing. *10,000 salaried civilian (unarmed) support personnel, including: **6,800 [[civil service|civil servants]] who perform administrative and support services. **2,000 [[Immigration to Germany|Immigration]] inspectors (called the Individual Service) who perform operational duty handling border protection and immigration matters and airline passenger checks. ==Organization== [[Image:Bundespolizei-Standortkarte.pdf|thumb|''Bundespolizei'' districts of Germany]] [[Image:Federal Police Patch.svg|thumb|130px|''Bundespolizei'' patch]] The BPOL national headquarters (BPOL-''Präsidium'') in [[Potsdam]] performs all central control functions. Eight regional headquarters (BPOL-''Direktion'') control the BPOL stations conduct rail police and border protection missions. These areas of responsibility conform to the federal state boundaries which they did not do prior to 1 March 2008. The regional headquarters are as follows: * [[Bad Bramstedt]] covering [[Schleswig-Holstein]] and [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]]. * [[Hanover]] covering [[Bremen]], [[Hamburg]] and [[Lower Saxony]]. * [[Sankt Augustin]] covering [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]. * [[Koblenz]] covering [[Saarland]], [[Rhineland-Palatinate]] and [[Hesse]]. * [[Stuttgart]] covering [[Baden-Württemberg]]. * [[Munich]] covering [[Bavaria]]. * [[Pirna]] covering [[Saxony]], [[Saxony-Anhalt]] and [[Thuringia]]. * [[Berlin]] covering [[Berlin]] and [[Brandenburg]]. These regional headquarters each have an investigation department and a mobile inspection and observation unit. Moreover, they control the 67 BPOL stations (BPOL-''Inspektion'') which in turn control the ''Bundespolizeireviere'' or precincts located in places that require a 24-hour presence by BPOL officers. A special ''Direktion'' is responsible for [[Frankfurt International Airport]]. The central school for advanced and vocational training is in Lübeck and controls the six basic training schools in [[Swisttal]], [[Neustrelitz]], [[Oerlenbach]], [[Walsrode]], [[Eschwege]] and [[Bamberg]]. It is also in charge of the Federal Police Sport School in [[Bad Endorf]] and a competitive sport project in Kienbaum near Berlin. The sport school specialises in winter sport events and has trained many of Germany's top skiers and skaters such as [[Claudia Pechstein]]. The ''Zentrale Direktion Bundesbereitschaftspolizei'' controls the mobile support and rapid reaction battalions located in [[Bayreuth]], [[Deggendorf]], Blumberg (near Berlin), [[Hünfeld]], [[Uelzen]], [[Duderstadt]], [[Sankt Augustin]], [[Bad Bergzabern]], [[Bad Düben]] and [[Ratzeburg]]. The number of ''[[Bereitschaftspolizei]]'' companies increased in March 2008 from 28 to 29 comprising approx. 25 percent of Germany’s police support units.[https://www.bundespolizei.de/cln_049/nn_249932/DE/Home/__Startseite/Neuorganisation/070426__konzept__neuorganisation,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/070426_konzept_neuorganisation.pdf Official BPOL news release on reorganisation (in German)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716175600/http://www.bundespolizei.de/cln_049/nn_249932/DE/Home/__Startseite/Neuorganisation/070426__konzept__neuorganisation%2CtemplateId%3Draw%2Cproperty%3DpublicationFile.pdf/070426_konzept_neuorganisation.pdf |date=2011-07-16 }} ===BPOL Special Units=== The following special units also exist: * The BPOL Aviation Group is directly subordinate to the BPOL HQ in Potsdam. It controls the five aviation squadrons around the country that operate the force's helicopters. These are located in [[Fuhlendorf, Schleswig-Holstein|Fuhlendorf]] (north, with satellite airfield in [[Gifhorn]]), Blumberg (east), Fuldatal (centre), [[Oberschleißheim]] (south) and Sankt Augustin (west). Its duties include; border surveillance, monitoring installations belonging to German Rail, helping in serious accidents and disasters in Germany and abroad, searching for missing persons, searching for criminals on the run, supporting the [[Landespolizei|police forces of the federal states]], providing transportation for persons whose security is endangered, providing transportation for guests of the Federal government, supporting federal and state authorities, and providing air search and rescue services in coordination with the 12 air rescue centers throughout Germany. * The [[GSG 9]] [[counter-terrorism]] group is directly subordinate to the BPOL HQ. * The BPOL Information and Communications Center is now a department of the BPOL HQ in Potsdam. * The [[water police]] stations with 16 patrol craft{{cite web |url=https://www.bundespolizei.de/DE/06Die-Bundespolizei/Ausstattung/Boote/boote_node.html |title=Einsatzschiffe sowie Kontroll- und Streifenboote |trans-title=Cruise and patrol vessels |publisher=Bundespolizei |language=German |accessdate=18 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120724140040/http://www.bundespolizei.de/DE/06Die-Bundespolizei/Ausstattung/Boote/boote_node.html |archivedate=24 July 2012 |df= }} and helicopters are part of the [[German Federal Coast Guard]] and assigned to coastal BPOL stations. The watercraft include six offshore patrol vessels, e.g. those of the [[Bad Bramstedt class patrol vessel|''Bad Bramstedt'' class]], as well as a number of fast inshore vessels and one [[tugboat]]. {{Clear}} ==History== [[Image:Bundesadler.bgs.JPG|thumb|120px|''Bundesgrenzschutz'' patch (1952 to 1976)]] In 1951 the West German government established a Federal Border Protection Force (''Bundesgrenzschutz'' or BGS) composed of 10,000 men under the Federal Interior Ministry’s jurisdiction. The force replaced allied military organisations such as the [[U.S. Constabulary]] then patrolling West Germany’s borders. The BGS was described as a mobile, lightly armed police force for border and internal security despite fears that it would be the nucleus of a new German army. When West Germany did establish an army, the [[Bundeswehr]], BGS personnel were given the choice of staying in the BGS or joining the army. Most decided to join the army. In 1953, the BGS took control of the German Passport Control Service. In 1972 the [[Compulsory Border Guard Service]] was enacted by the parliament, which - in theory - is still in force, but suspended, similar to the conscription for the [[Bundeswehr]].http://dipbt.bundestag.de/doc/brd/1994/D840+94.pdfhttps://books.google.at/books?id=RcPPBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA57&lpg=PA57&dq=Grenzschutzdienstpflicht&source=bl&ots=dI2L9pnpEV&sig=evQ1ihN3bdIYICFjdNFr8fdlWgY&hl=de&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiBirvW4ZTdAhXqkIsKHbh3DHA4ChDoATAAegQIABAB#v=onepage&q=Grenzschutzdienstpflicht&f=false In 1976, the state police grades replaced the military rank structure and BGS training was modified to closely match that of the state police forces (''[[Landespolizei]]''). The West German Railway Police (''[[Bahnpolizei]]''), formerly an independent force, and the East German ''[[Transportpolizei]]'' were restructured under the BGS in 1990. In July 2005, the BGS was renamed the ''Bundespolizei'' or BPOL (Federal Police) to reflect its transition to a multi-faceted federal police agency. The change also involved a shift to blue uniforms and livery for vehicles and helicopters. The German Interior Ministry reviewed the structure of the BPOL in 2007 and in March 2008 made the structure leaner to get more officers out of offices and onto patrol. ==Vehicles== [[Image:BPOL-BMW-blau-silber.JPG|thumb|right|BMW standard patrol car]] [[Image:BG34-71.JPG|right|thumb|A ''Bundespolizei'' van]] ''Bundespolizei'' vehicles have number plates that are based on the BP XX-YYY system. BP stands for ''Bundespolizei.'' Older vehicles may still have the BGS "BG" plates. XX is a number from 10 to 55 indicating the type of vehicle: *10 to 12: Motorcycle *15 to 19: Car *20 to 24: Four wheel drive car *25 to 29: Car *30 to 39: Medium four wheel drive vehicle *40 to 49: Trucks and buses *50 to 54: Armoured cars. *55: Trailers YYY is a combination of up to three numbers. The ''Bundespolizei'' have favoured, and in some cases still favor (where the model is still in production), the following types of car: * [[BMW]] [[BMW 5 Series|5 Series sedans and station wagons]] * [[Volkswagen Passat]] sedans and Variant station wagons * [[Volkswagen Golf]] * [[Volkswagen Transporter]] vans [[Image:2006-08 Frankfurt (Oder) 11.jpg|thumb|right|BMW R 1150 RT motorcycle]] ==Weaponry== This is some of the weaponry utilized by the Federal Police: * [[H&K G36]] * [[H&K MP5]] * [[H&K P30]] ==Aircraft inventory== The Federal Police now has been reduced to three flight amenities pattern of 87 helicopters. This is the largest civilian helicopter fleet in Germany.{{cite web |url=http://www.bundespolizei.de/DE/06Die-Bundespolizei/Historie/historie_node.html |title=Historie der Bundespolizei |accessdate=2015-04-04 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928045244/http://www.bundespolizei.de/DE/06Die-Bundespolizei/Historie/historie_node.html |archivedate=September 28, 2011 |df= }} [[File:EC135Bundespolizei.jpg|thumb|A [[Eurocopter EC-135]] of the ''Bundespolizei'' in the new livery]] [[File:AS 332 Super Puma Tannkosh 2010.jpg|thumb|''Bundespolizei'' [[Eurocopter Super Puma]]]] [[Image:Eurocopter EC 155 B r.jpg|thumb|''Bundespolizei'' [[Eurocopter Dauphin|Eurocopter EC-155]]]] {| class="wikitable" ! style="text-align: left;"|Aircraft ! style="text-align: left;"|Type ! style="text-align: left;"|Versions ! style="text-align: left;"|In service ! style="text-align: left;"|Notes |- | [[Eurocopter EC-120]] || training helicopter || EC 120|| 6 || replaced Allouette II in training role |- | [[Bell 212]] || rescue- / transport helicopter || Bell 212 || 5 || to be replaced by 5 EC-155 in 2010-2012 |- | [[Eurocopter Super Puma]] || transport helicopter || AS 332 L1 || 19 || 3 more on order http://strategie-technik.blogspot.de/2016/12/nh90-sea-lion-absolviert-jungfernflug.html |- | [[Eurocopter EC 135]] || utility helicopter || EC 135 || 42 || replaced Allouette II, Bell UH-1D in liaison and MEDEVAC role |- | [[Eurocopter EC 155]] || transport helicopter || EC 155 B || 15 || 5 further EC-155 ordered to replace remaining Bell 212 |} ===Former aircraft=== {| class="wikitable" ! style="text-align: left;"|Aircraft ! style="text-align: left;"|Type ! style="text-align: left;"|Versions ! style="text-align: left;"|In service ! style="text-align: left;"|Notes |- | [[Aérospatiale Alouette II]] || training and utility helicopter || SA 318C || - || last Allouette left the fleet in 2007 |- | [[Aérospatiale Puma]] || transport helicopter || SA 330 || - || last Puma left the fleet in 2008, replaced by Super Pumas |- | [[MBB Bo 105]] || rescue helicopter || Bo 105CBS || - || replaced by [[Eurocopter EC-135]]T2i |} ==K-9 support== Approximately 500 working dogs are used in the Federal Police at present. Most of the dogs are [[German shepherd]]s. Other dog breeds are also used such as [[Belgian Shepherd Dog (Malinois)|malinois]], [[Dutch shepherd]], [[German wirehaired pointer]], [[giant schnauzer]], and [[rottweiler]]. They accompany their handlers on daily missions in railway facilities, at airports, at the border or in physical security. Most working dogs live with the families of their handlers. Basic and advanced training is performed under the supervision of the Federal Police Academy at the Federal Police canine schools in [[Bleckede]] (Lower Saxony) and [[Neuendettelsau]] (Bavaria) where dogs and handlers go through patrol dog and explosive detection courses. ==Ranks== [[Image:Coast guard MS Bredstedt.jpg|right|thumb|''Bundespolizei'' cutter BP 21 ''Bredstedt'']] '''Junior ranks (''Mittlerer Dienst'')''' {| class="prettytable" align="center" !bgcolor="silver"|Rank !bgcolor="silver"|Translation !bgcolor="silver"|Rank insignia !bgcolor="silver"|Equivalent rank
